column2: EXERCISE LEADERSHIP FOR THE OLDER ADULT
column6: Designed to provide the students with a knowledge base in exercise leadership in the senior population and includes special populations. Students participate in the leading supervision and evaluation of the participant within the exercise program. They also assist in the collection of functional fitness data.

column2: VARIABEL TITLE WORKSHOP IN EXERCISE SCIENCE AND EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY
column6: Workshop in exercise science or physiology, topics vary.
Lecture and laboratory experiences dealing with the administration and interpretation of exercise tests.

Designed to provide students with the knowledge base in electrocardiography. Students work on interpreting the 12-lead electrocardiogram with clinical case studies to enhance the knowledge base of the exercise specialist.
Physiological bases of muscular activity with special attention to general effects of exercise on body function. Laboratory included.

column2: PHYSIOLOGY OF AGING: IMPLICATIONS FOR HUMAN BEHAVIOR
column6: Examine physiological changes which accompany advancing age. Special attention is paid to the effect of these changes on sensory motor and cognitive behavior.

column2: RESEARCH PROCESS IN ATHLETIC TRAINING AND EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY
column6: The research process and statistical concepts applied to athletic training and exercise physiology.

column2: QUANTITATIVE AND RESEARCH METHODS IN ATHLETIC TRAINING AND EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY
column6: Research design and statistical methods applied to exercise, physiology and athletic training.
Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students. A total of 2 credits may be applied toward degree requirements.
Independent study completed under the supervision of a faculty member. Written approval of supervising faculty member and school Director required prior to registration. Repeatable to 6 credit hours.
Research or individual investigation. Repeated registration permitted.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY
column6: Workshop in exercise physiology; topics vary. Repeated registration permitted. Maximum 4 hours applied to the degree.
Selected and varied topics of relevance in exercise physiology.
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.

column2: PHYSIOLOGICAL BASIS OF EXERCISE AND SPORT
column6: Application of physiological concepts to human performance. Includes role of testing, training strength and endurance, nutritional considerations, environmental influences and, adapted exercise programs.
Measurement of metabolic response to exercise. Topics include ergometry spirometry energy expenditure body composition and performance correlates of strength power and endurance.

Measurement of the cardiovascular-respiratory response to exercise. Includes resting spirometry, lung function during exercise, electrocardiography, blood pressure, PWC testing and exercise prescription.
Field experience in exercise physiology programs and testing in Kent State University adult fitness program or cooperating agencies. May be repeated for a total of 8 credit hours.

column2: PHYSIOLOGY OF AGING: IMPLICATIONS FOR HUMAN BEHAVIOR
column6: Examine physiological changes which accompany advancing age. Special attention is paid to the effect of these changes on sensory motor and cognitive behavior.

column2: ADVANCED RESEARCH DESIGN AND STATISTICS IN EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY
column6: Advanced topics in research design and statistical analysis with computer applications in exercise physiology.
Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students. A total of 2 credits may be applied toward degree requirements.
Survey of biomechanics, with particular emphasis on skeletal muscle mechanics.
Responses of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems to exercise. Use of noninvasive methods to measure cardio-respiratory function emphasized. Lecture and laboratory.
Characteristics of skeletal muscle related to contraction during exercise, strength, elasticity, fatigue and training. Electromyography analysis of muscle function emphasized.
Effects of heat, cold, pressure, pollution and psychological stress upon physiological responses to exercise. Lecture and laboratory.

column2: PHYSIOLOGICAL BASIS OF EXERCISE AND SPORT
column6: Application of physiological concepts to human performance. Includes role of testing, training, strength and endurance, nutritional considerations, environmental influences, and adapted exercise programs.
Measurement of metabolic response to exercise. Topics include ergometry, spirometry, energy expenditure, body composition and performance correlates of strength, power and endurance.

Measurement of the cardiovascular-respiratory response to exercise. Includes resting spirometry, lung function during exercise, electrocardiography, blood pressure, PWC testing and exercise prescription.
Energy transformations during exercise. Emphasis on controlling mechanisms that regulate the anabolic and catabolic responses to both acute and chronic exercise.
Responses of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems to exercise. Use of noninvasive methods to measure cardio-respiratory function emphasized. Lecture and laboratory.

column2: ANTHROPOMETRY AND BODY COMPOSITION IN THE EXERCISE SCIENCES
column6: Theory of selected procedures for the measurement of body composition and physique and their applications in the sports sciences. Laboratory seminar format.
Field experience in exercise physiology programs and testing in KSU adult fitness program or cooperating agencies. May be repeated up to 8 credit hours.
Research for doctoral students.

Doctoral dissertation, for which registration in at least two semesters is required, first of which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.
